questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding javascript language?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding javascript language?

options.option_text: Hoisting moves the declaration of arrow functions to the top of their scopes.
All 3 keywords, i.e., “var”, “let” and “const” can be used to declare globalvariables.
The functions are treated as first class citizens in the language.
Node.js is an example of a javascript engine.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about cookies and CORS?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about cookies and CORS?

options.option_text: A session cookie expires as soon as the browser is closed.
The CORS mechanism reduces the chances of malicious actions by explicitlysaying which URLs can be the originators of data.
A browser sandbox causes any browser based malware to directly affect theuser’s system.
All of these

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false about pub/sub messaging?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false about pub/sub messaging?

options.option_text: Publisher has to know about all the subscribers.
Publisher does not have to know about the subscribers.
Communication between publisher and subscribers is asynchronous.
Communication between publishers and subscribers is synchronous.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: In short polling, the server does not respond until the data is available or therequest times out.
In long polling, the server does not respond until the data is available or therequest times out.
In short polling, the server responds immediately with or without data.
In long polling, the server responds immediately with or without data.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is false regarding a message broker?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is false regarding a message broker?

options.option_text: A message broker allows two servers in a network to directly communicatewith each other, without an intermediary.
A message broker makes the network scalable for adding more servers to thenetwork.
A message broker can be used for batch processing of messages.
A message broker is well suited in case of traffic spikes, as messages areretained in the queue until processed.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is incorrect regarding the prototype in JavaScript?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is incorrect regarding the prototype in JavaScript?

options.option_text: Every constructor function has a property named ‘prototype’.
Any object created using the new keyword and the constructor function, willinherit from the constructor’s prototype object.
Prototype of an object can be accessed using the ‘__proto__’ property of theobject.
The prototype of an object can be accessed using the ‘prototype’ property ofthe object.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding forward and reverse proxy?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding forward and reverse proxy?

options.option_text: A forward proxy is used to protect the server(s) from the outside world.
A reverse proxy can be used to cache the responses, to reuse them for similarsubsequent requests.
A load balancer becomes irrelevant, where there is not more than 1 server.
An efficient load balancer must use a round-robin algorithm.

Suppose you are building an application which requires sending emails to all the users stored in the database at regular intervals. Given below are the two approaches to satisfy the requirement.    Choose the correct statement(s).

options.option_text: Approach 1 will take more time than approach 2, if more than 2 celery workersare available.
Approach 2 will take more time than approach 1, if more than 2 celery workersare available.
Both the approaches will take same time (approx), if only 1 celery worker isavailable.
None of these

options.option_text: A webhook should deliver data to other apps, as it happens.
A webhook is primarily meant for a server to server communication.

A webhook and web socket is essentially the same.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose an endpoint in your flask application triggers a celery task, which generates a CSV file named “data.csv” and saves it in the static folder of a flask application. The file generator takes anywhere between 20 and 40 seconds to generate and save the CSV file.  The below fetch call is used to get the file generated by the above explained celery task.
questions.question_text_2: Suppose an endpoint in your flask application triggers a celery task, which generates a CSV file named “data.csv” and saves it in the static folder of a flask application. The file generator takes anywhere between 20 and 40 seconds to generate and save the CSV file.  The below fetch call is used to get the file generated by the above explained celery task.    Which of the following is the most efficient way to make the above fetch call so that it doesn’t fail and return the desired response?
question_texts: Suppose an endpoint in your flask application triggers a celery task, which generates a CSV file named “data.csv” and saves it in the static folder of a flask application. The file generator takes anywhere between 20 and 40 seconds to generate and save the CSV file.  The below fetch call is used to get the file generated by the above explained celery task.

Suppose an endpoint in your flask application triggers a celery task, which generates a CSV file named “data.csv” and saves it in the static folder of a flask application. The file generator takes anywhere between 20 and 40 seconds to generate and save the CSV file.  The below fetch call is used to get the file generated by the above explained celery task.    Which of the following is the most efficient way to make the above fetch call so that it doesn’t fail and return the desired response?

options.option_text: Use short polling to check the state of the celery task after every 5 seconds,and make the fetch call, when the task succeeds.
Use javascript function “setTimeout” to make the fetch after 41 seconds, whichmakes sure that the file is generated and saved to the desired location.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development 2"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ### **1. JavaScript Core Concepts** #### **Key Topics:** - **Hoisting**: - `var` declarations are hoisted and initialized with `undefined`. - `let`/`const` declarations are hoisted but **not initialized** (Temporal Dead Zone). - **Arrow functions** are **not hoisted** (unlike function declarations). - Example: ```javascript console.log(x); // undefined (var) console.log(y); // ReferenceError (let/const) var x = 5; let y = 10; ``` - **Variable Scoping**: - `var`: Function-scoped or global. - `let`/`const`: Block-scoped. - **Global variables**: All 3 (`var`, `let`, `const`) can declare globals if not in a block/function. - **First-Class Functions**: - Functions can be: - Assigned to variables. - Passed as arguments. - Returned from other functions. - **Arrow Functions vs. Regular Functions**: - Arrow functions: - No `this` binding (lexical scoping). - No `arguments` object. - Cannot be used as constructors. - **Asynchronous JavaScript**: - **Promises**: `.then()`, `.catch()`, `.finally()`. - **Async/Await**: Syntactic sugar for promises. - Example: ```javascript async function demo() { let prom = new Promise((res) => setTimeout(() => res(46), 2000)); console.log("Statement 2"); return prom; } demo().then((result) => console.log(result)); console.log("Statement 1"); // Output: "Statement 2", "Statement 1", 46 ``` - **`this` Binding**: - Determined by **how a function is called** (not where it’s defined). - `.bind()`, `.call()`, `.apply()` can override `this`. - Example: ```javascript const obj = { num: 10 }; function func() { console.log(this.num); } func.call(obj); // 10 ``` #### **Mermaid Graph: JavaScript Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[JavaScript] --> B[Hoisting] A --> C[Scoping] A --> D[First-Class Functions] A --> E[Asynchronous JS] A --> F[this Binding] B --> B1[var: Hoisted & Initialized] B --> B2[let/const: Hoisted but Uninitialized] B --> B3[Arrow Functions: Not Hoisted] C --> C1[var: Function/Global Scope] C --> C2[let/const: Block Scope] D --> D1[Assigned to Variables] D --> D2[Passed as Arguments] D --> D3[Returned from Functions] E --> E1[Promises: .then/.catch] E --> E2[Async/Await] F --> F1[Determined by Call Context] F --> F2[.bind/.call/.apply] ``` --- --- ### **2. Web Technologies** #### **Key Topics:** - **Cookies**: - **Session Cookie**: Expires when the browser closes. - **Persistent Cookie**: Expires at a set time (`Expires`/`Max-Age`). - **SameSite Attribute**: Controls cross-site cookie sending (`Strict`, `Lax`, `None`). - **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**: - **Same-Origin Policy**: Blocks requests to different origins (protocol + domain + port). - **CORS Headers**: - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`: Specifies allowed origins. - `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`: Allowed HTTP methods. - Example: ```http Access-Control-Allow-Origin: http://example.com ``` - **Browser Sandbox**: - Isolates web pages from the system/other tabs. - **Malware cannot directly affect the system** (unless exploits exist). #### **Mermaid Graph: Web Technologies** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Technologies] --> B[Cookies] A --> C[CORS] A --> D[Browser Sandbox] B --> B1[Session Cookie] B --> B2[Persistent Cookie] B --> B3[SameSite Attribute] C --> C1[Same-Origin Policy] C --> C2[CORS Headers] C --> C3[Access-Control-Allow-Origin] D --> D1[Isolates Web Pages] D --> D2[Prevents Direct System Access] ``` --- --- ### **3. Pub/Sub Messaging** #### **Key Topics:** - **Publisher-Subscriber Model**: - **Publisher**: Sends messages to a **topic/queue** without knowing subscribers. - **Subscriber**: Receives messages from the topic/queue. - **Asynchronous**: Publisher and subscribers operate independently. - **Message Brokers** (e.g., RabbitMQ, Kafka): - Decouples publishers and subscribers. - **Features**: - Retains messages in queues. - Handles traffic spikes. - Supports batch processing. - **Comparison with Direct Communication**: | Feature | Pub/Sub | Direct Communication | |-----------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------------| | Coupling | Loose | Tight | | Scalability | High | Low | | Asynchronous | Yes | No (usually synchronous) | #### **Mermaid Graph: Pub/Sub Messaging** ```mermaid graph TD A[Pub/Sub Messaging] --> B[Publisher] A --> C[Subscriber] A --> D[Message Broker] B --> B1[Sends to Topic/Queue] B --> B2[No Knowledge of Subscribers] C --> C1[Listens to Topic/Queue] C --> C2[Processes Messages Asynchronously] D --> D1[Decouples Publisher/Subscriber] D --> D2[Retains Messages] D --> D3[Handles Traffic Spikes] ``` --- --- ### **4. Polling vs. Long Polling vs. WebSockets** #### **Key Topics:** | Technique | Description | Pros | Cons | |----------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------|-------------------------------| | **Short Polling** | Client polls server at fixed intervals. | Simple to implement. | High latency, inefficient. | | **Long Polling** | Server holds request until data is available or timeout occurs. | Lower latency than short polling. | Complex to implement. | | **WebSockets** | Persistent full-duplex connection between client and server. | Real-time, low latency. | Requires WebSocket support. | - **Key Differences**: - **Short Polling**: Server responds immediately (with or without data). - **Long Polling**: Server waits for data or timeout before responding. #### **Mermaid Graph: Polling Techniques** ```mermaid graph TD A[Client-Server Communication] --> B[Short Polling] A --> C[Long Polling] A --> D[WebSockets] B --> B1[Fixed Interval Requests] B --> B2[Server Responds Immediately] C --> C1[Server Holds Request] C --> C2[Responds on Data/Timeout] D --> D1[Persistent Connection] D --> D2[Full-Duplex Communication] ``` --- --- ### **5. REST API** #### **Key Topics:** - **HTTP Methods**: | Method | Idempotent | Safe | Description | |--------|------------|------|--------------------------------------| | GET | Yes | Yes | Retrieve data. | | POST | No | No | Create resource. | | PUT | Yes | No | Replace resource (full update). | | PATCH | No | No | Partial update. | | DELETE | Yes | No | Delete resource. | - **Idempotency**: - An operation is **idempotent** if repeating it has the same effect as doing it once. - Example: `DELETE /users/1` is idempotent; `POST /users` is not. - **Statelessness**: - Each request must contain all necessary information (no server-side session storage). #### **Mermaid Graph: REST API** ```mermaid graph TD A[REST API] --> B[HTTP Methods] A --> C[Idempotency] A --> D[Statelessness] B --> B1[GET: Idempotent & Safe] B --> B2[POST: Non-Idempotent] B --> B3[PUT: Idempotent] B --> B4[DELETE: Idempotent] C --> C1[Same Effect on Repeat] C --> C2[Examples: GET, PUT, DELETE] D --> D1[No Server-Side Sessions] D --> D2[Each Request is Independent] ``` --- --- ### **6. Vue.js** #### **Key Topics:** - **Vue Instance Lifecycle**: `beforeCreate` → `created` → `beforeMount` → `mounted` → `beforeUpdate` → `updated` → `beforeDestroy` → `destroyed` - **Components**: - Reusable Vue instances with their own templates, data, and methods. - **Props**: Pass data from parent to child. - **Slots**: Distribute content from parent to child. - **Directives**: - `v-if`/`v-show`: Conditional rendering. - `v-for`: Loop over arrays/objects. - `v-model`: Two-way data binding. - `v-bind`: Bind attributes (`:class`, `:style`). - `v-on`: Listen to events (`@click`). - **Vue Router**: - Dynamic routing for SPAs. - **`router-view`**: Renders matched component. - **`router-link`**: Navigation links. - Example: ```javascript const router = new VueRouter({ routes: [ { path: '/profile/:id', component: Profile }, { path: '*', component: NotFound } ] }); ``` - **Vuex (State Management)**: - **Store**: Single source of truth. - **State**: Reactive data. - **Getters**: Computed properties for state. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state changes. - **Actions**: Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - Example: ```javascript const store = new Vuex.Store({ state: { count: 0 }, mutations: { increment(state) { state.count++; } } }); ``` - **Dynamic Class Binding**: - Syntax: `:class="{ 'active': isActive }"` - Example: ```html
``` #### **Mermaid Graph: Vue.js Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Vue.js] --> B[Lifecycle Hooks] A --> C[Components] A --> D[Directives] A --> E[Vue Router] A --> F[Vuex] B --> B1[beforeCreate/created] B --> B2[beforeMount/mounted] B --> B3[beforeUpdate/updated] C --> C1[Reusable Instances] C --> C2[Props & Slots] C --> C3[Template/Data/Methods] D --> D1[v-if/v-show] D --> D2[v-for] D --> D3[v-model] D --> D4[v-bind/v-on] E --> E1[Dynamic Routing] E --> E2[router-view] E --> E3[router-link] F --> F1[Store: Single Source] F --> F2[State/Getters] F --> F3[Mutations/Actions] ``` --- --- ### **7. Proxies (Forward vs. Reverse)** #### **Key Topics:** | Proxy Type | Description | Use Cases | |------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------| | **Forward Proxy** | Acts on behalf of **clients** (hides client identities). | Bypass restrictions, cache requests. | | **Reverse Proxy** | Acts on behalf of **servers** (hides server identities). | Load balancing, caching, security. | - **Load Balancing**: - Distributes traffic across multiple servers. - Algorithms: Round Robin, Least Connections, IP Hash. - **Caching**: - Reverse proxies (e.g., Nginx) can cache responses to reduce server load. #### **Mermaid Graph: Proxies** ```mermaid graph TD A[Proxies] --> B[Forward Proxy] A --> C[Reverse Proxy] B --> B1[Client-Side] B --> B2[Hides Client IP] B --> B3[Bypasses Restrictions] C --> C1[Server-Side] C --> C2[Hides Server IP] C --> C3[Load Balancing] C --> C4[Caching] ``` --- --- ### **8. Celery (Task Queue)** #### **Key Topics:** - **Asynchronous Task Execution**: - Offloads long-running tasks (e.g., sending emails, generating reports). - Example: ```python @celery.task def send_email(email): # Send email logic send_email.delay("user@example.com") # Enqueue task ``` - **Workers**: - Multiple workers can process tasks in parallel. - **Approach 1 (Bulk Task)**: - Single task processes all users sequentially. - Slower with 1 worker; no benefit from multiple workers. - **Approach 2 (Individual Tasks)**: - Each user is a separate task. - Faster with multiple workers (parallel processing). - **Polling for Task Status**: - Use **short polling** or **Celery Result Backend** (e.g., Redis) to check task status. #### **Mermaid Graph: Celery** ```mermaid graph TD A[Celery] --> B[Task Queue] A --> C[Workers] A --> D[Polling] B --> B1[Offloads Long Tasks] B --> B2[@celery.task Decorator] C --> C1[Single Worker: Sequential] C --> C2[Multiple Workers: Parallel] D --> D1[Short Polling] D --> D2[Result Backend: Redis] ``` --- --- ### **9. Flask & Caching** #### **Key Topics:** - **Flask-Caching**: - Caches responses to reduce server load. - **Backends**: Redis, Memcached, filesystem. - Example: ```python @cache.memoize(timeout=120) def get_score(name): sleep(10) # Simulate slow operation return 0 ``` - **`memoize`**: Caches based on function arguments. - **Timeout**: Cache expires after 120 seconds. - **Redis**: - In-memory data store used for caching. - **Key-Value Store**: Fast read/write operations. #### **Mermaid Graph: Flask Caching** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask Caching] --> B[Flask-Caching] A --> C[Redis] B --> B1[@cache.memoize] B --> B2[Timeout] B --> B3[Reduces Server Load] C --> C1[In-Memory Store] C --> C2[Key-Value Cache] ``` --- --- ### **10. Webhooks** #### **Key Topics:** - **Definition**: - User-defined HTTP callbacks triggered by events (e.g., GitHub push, Stripe payment). - **How It Works**: 1. **Sender** (e.g., GitHub) sends an HTTP POST to a **receiver URL** (your server). 2. **Receiver** processes the data (e.g., updates a database). - **vs. WebSockets**: - **Webhooks**: One-way, event-driven (server → client). - **WebSockets**: Full-duplex, persistent connection. #### **Mermaid Graph: Webhooks** ```mermaid graph TD A[Webhooks] --> B[Event-Driven] A --> C[HTTP POST] A --> D[vs. WebSockets] B --> B1[Triggered by Events] B --> B2[Example: GitHub Push] C --> C1[Sender to Receiver URL] C --> C2[JSON Payload] D --> D1[Webhooks: One-Way] D --> D2[WebSockets: Full-Duplex] ``` --- --- ### **Summary of Equations (Math/Algorithms)** No mathematical equations were present in the questions, but here are **key algorithmic concepts** relevant to the exam: 1. **Array Operations** (JavaScript): - `map`: Transforms each element. ```javascript const b = a.map(x => x ** 2); // [4, 25, 64, ...] ``` - `filter`: Returns elements matching a condition. ```javascript const c = b.filter(x => x % 2); // Odd numbers ``` - `find`: Returns the first element matching a condition. ```javascript const d = c.find(x => x % 3 === 1); // First odd number ≡ 1 mod 3 ``` 2. **Asynchronous Flow**: - Promise chaining: ```javascript fetchData() .then(data => process(data)) .catch(error => handle(error)); ``` - Async/await: ```javascript async function fetch() { const data = await fetchData(); console.log(data); } ``` 3. **Vue.js Reactivity**: - Computed properties: ```javascript computed: { average() { return this.stat.totalRun / this.stat.totalMatches; } } ``` --- --- ### **Final Mermaid Graph: Full Topic Relationships** ```mermaid graph TD A[Modern Application Development] --> B[JavaScript] A --> C[Web Technologies] A --> D[Pub/Sub Messaging] A --> E[REST API] A --> F[Vue.js] A --> G[Proxies] A --> H[Celery] A --> I[Flask & Caching] A --> J[Webhooks] B --> B1[Hoisting/Scoping] B --> B2[First-Class Functions] B --> B3[Async/Await] C --> C1[Cookies/CORS] C --> C2[Browser Sandbox] D --> D1[Publisher/Subscriber] D --> D2[Message Brokers] E --> E1[HTTP Methods] E --> E2[Idempotency] F --> F1[Lifecycle Hooks] F --> F2[Components] F --> F3[Vuex] G --> G1[Forward Proxy] G --> G2[Reverse Proxy] H --> H1[Task Queue] H --> H2[Workers] I --> I1[Flask-Caching] I --> I2[Redis] J --> J1[Event-Driven] J --> J2[HTTP POST] ``` --- --- ### **Exam Preparation Tips** 1. **JavaScript**: - Practice hoisting, `this` binding, and async/await. - Understand `map`/`filter`/`find` chaining. 2. **Vue.js**: - Focus on **component lifecycle**, **slots**, **Vue Router**, and **Vuex**. - Practice dynamic class binding and computed properties. 3. **REST API**: - Memorize HTTP methods and idempotency rules. 4. **Pub/Sub & Celery**: - Understand decoupling and parallel task processing. 5. **Proxies & Caching**: - Know the difference between forward/reverse proxies and caching strategies. 6. **Webhooks**: - Compare with WebSockets and polling. 7. **Flask**: - Review `@cache.memoize` and Redis integration. --- **Good luck!** Let me know if you'd like deeper dives into any topic.
